Harriet Brandwein Cohen | spouse = {{marriage|[[Ronald Perelman]]|1985|1994|end=div}} | children = 1 | website = }} '''Claudia Lynn Cohen''' (December 16, 1950 – June 15, 2007) was an American gossip columnist, socialite, and television reporter. She is credited with putting the New York Post's Page Six gossip column on the map. The building housing the University of Pennsylvania's College of Arts and Sciences was renamed in her honor in 2008.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/06/fashion/06penn.html|title=At Penn, the Subject Is Gossip|last=Williams|first=Alex|date=2008-07-06|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-12-07|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} ==Early life and education== Claudia Cohen was born to a [[American Jews|Jewish]] family,{{Cite web|last= Morgan |first= Spencer |authorlink= |title= Remembering Claudia Cohen: Gossip's Most Generous Hostess Was Also Just Genuinely Good |publisher=[[New York Observer]]|date=June 20, 2007 |url= https://observer.com/2007/06/remembering-claudia-cohen-gossips-most-generous-hostess-was-also-just-genuinely-good/ |accessdate=}} the daughter of Harriet (n√©e Brandwein) and businessman [[Robert B. Cohen]], the founder of [[Hudson News]] and the president of the [[Hudson Group|Hudson County News Company]], a magazine wholesaler.{{cite news|first=Dennis|last=Hevesi|title=Robert B. Cohen, Hudson News Chain Founder, Dies at 86 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/06/business/media/robert-b-cohen-dies-at-85-founded-the-hudson-news-chain.html |work=[[The New York Times]] |publisher= |date=2012-02-05 |accessdate=2012-04-16}} She grew up in [[Englewood, New Jersey]], and attended the Dwight School for Girls (now the [[Dwight-Englewood School]]) and the [[University of Pennsylvania]].''Marquis Who's Who'' 2006 "Claudia Cohen" retrieved from Galenet 16 June 2007Staff. [https://www.nytimes.com/1985/01/12/style/claudia-cohen-reporter-weds-ronald-perelman.html "Claudia Cohen, Reporter, Weds Ronald Perelman"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', January 12, 1985. Accessed June 14, 2018. "She graduated from the Dwight School and the University of Pennsylvania." ==Journalism career== In 1976, she joined the ''[[New York Post]]'' as a reporter for its fledgling gossip column ''[[Page Six]]''. She succeeded Neal Travis as editor of ''[[Page Six]]'' in 1978. Noted for going for the jugular, and creating a column with savvy and a sharp edge, Cohen is credited with putting Page Six on the map. Cohen left the ''Post'' in 1980 to start her own short-lived gossip column, ''I, Claudia'' (a play on words of the book title ''[[I, Claudius]]'') at a rival newspaper, the New York Daily News. While that column was not a success, it did maintain Cohen's profile. Cohen was a regular on ''[[Live with Regis and Kelly]]'' and an active member of the Manhattan and Hamptons social scene.Olshan, Jeremy (16 June 2007). [http://www.nypost.com/p/news/regional/item_kulMLHck7dZvtRtRMfnPMJ Gossip Will Be Heavenly: Ex-Six-Pager Cohen Dies], ''New York Post'' ==Death== Cohen died on June 15, 2007 from [[ovarian cancer]].Fox, Margalit. [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/06/16/nyregion/16cohen.html Claudia Cohen, 56, Socialite and a Reporter of Gossip, Is Dead]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. June 16, 2007. ==Personal life== In 1984, Cohen began a relationship with businessman [[Ronald Perelman]]. The two married in 1985, and had one daughter, Samantha. After nine years, the couple divorced, and Cohen reportedly received a settlement of $80,000,000 (eighty million U.S. dollars).''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'' "THE TROPHY WIFE IS BACK--WITH BRAINS" 03/04/95 (retrieved through Australia New Zealand Reference Centre) Cohen later dated former U.S. senator from New York state, [[Al D'Amato]].''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'', Ibid At the request of Ronald Perelman, the University of Pennsylvania renamed the historic Logan Hall, sitting next to [[College Hall (University of Pennsylvania)|College Hall]] and originally named after [[James Logan (statesman)|James Logan]], secretary to [[William Penn]], "Claudia Cohen Hall," much to the surprise and dismay of some Penn faculty, alumni, and students. The rear of the newly renamed building overlooks [[University of Pennsylvania Perelman Quadrangle|Perelman Quadrangle]].Wu, Cecily.
